ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Removal of oxygen from silicon by electron beam melting

Affiliation.OrgDivision: School of Materials Science and Engineering

Affiliation.OrgName: Key Laboratory for Solar Energy Photovoltaic System of Liaoning Province
Balochistan University of Information Technology Engineering and Management Sciences

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Small amounts of multicrystalline silicon were melted in an electron beam furnace in different experimental conditions in order to investigate the oxygen evaporation behavior during the electron beam melting (EBM) process. The oxygen content level before and after EBM was determined by secondary ion mass spectroscopy. The oxygen content was reduced from 6.177 to 1.629 ppmw when silicon was melted completely at 15 kW with removal efficiency up to 73.6 %. After that, it decreased continually to <0.0517 ppmw when the refining time exceeded 600 s with a removal efficiency of more than 99.08 %. During the melting process, the evaporation rate of silicon is 1.10 × 10−5 kg/s. The loss of silicon could be reduced up to 1.7 % during oxygen removal process to a desirable figure, indicating EBM is an effective method to remove oxygen from silicon and decrease the loss of silicon.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Contemporary research focusing on low cost and high efficiency of solar cells having long life time with minimum zero level contamination has bright future [1]. In modern period, the consumption of solar-grade silicon (SoG-Si) is increasing day by day with rapid improvement of photovoltaic industry [2, 3]. Metallurgical-grade silicon (MG-Si) has been considered as feedstock to fabricate high-quality multicrystalline silicon ingots directly by refining impurities [4, 5]. MG-Si to SoG-Si provides the fundamental groundwork for further development of photovoltaic industry [6–9].

As the last step of metallurgical process, pure silicon is loaded in a quartz (SiO2) crucible where it is melted and reacts with the crucible walls, inducing the oxygen contamination. The presence of oxygen degrades the electrical performance of silicon solar cells due to its interaction with boron to form B–O complexes and with carbon to form C–O complexes and segregating as oxide, etc. Oxygen content for solar-grade silicon should be <0.7 ppmw, and the minority carrier lifetime should be more than 2 μs [10]. Solidification mechanism in silicon casting ingot production is achieved through directional solidification. During this processing, 30 % of the ingot is wasted due to the incorporation of oxygen around ingot–crucible contact areas [11]. In China, about 120,000 tons of this kind of material is wasted every year.

The removal of oxygen from titanium alloy by electron beam melting (EBM) has been reported [12], but removal of oxygen from the silicon melt by EBM is a unique idea. EBM is characterized by high vacuum and high temperature. The EBM has been widely applied to refractory, reactive metals and is now used for purifying materials, specifically for impurities with high vapor pressure [13–15].

In this paper, a series of melting experiments were carried out to obtain the content of oxygen in silicon ingot after electron beam melting with different melting time. In order to clarify the removal mechanism of oxygen, the evaporation coefficient of oxygen and the kinetic behavior on evaporation of oxygen from the melt free surface were investigated. The relationship between oxygen’s evaporation and silicon loss was also discussed.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para:
The silicon samples were extracted from the bottom of a casted ingot, where the material presents the major contamination with oxygen (up to 6.177 ppmw). Before melting by electron beam, the sample was properly washed in alcohol by a supersonic wave cleaner in order to remove possible solid residues. For each experiment, 300 g of silicon was placed in a water-cooled copper crucible. After the pressure of the chamber and the electron beam gun was evacuated to less than 5.0 × 10−2 and 5.0 × 10−3 Pa, respectively, the filament and cathode were then preheated. Later, the melting process was performed. The electron beam with a power of 15 kW was irradiated on the surface of the silicon until it was melted. Once silicon was melted completely, the electron beam was stopped instantaneously after the molten pool was held for a certain time. The melting time of zero was defined as the state, in which the silicon was melted completely in the crucible. The silicon solidified in short time and was removed from the crucible after cooling for 30 min. The melting parameters are shown in Table 1.

The morphologies of the silicon ingot and the cross section are shown in Fig. 1. Weight loss of silicon ingots was recorded after the EBM process. The oxygen content levels were determined by secondary ion mass spectroscopy (SIMS) before and after electron beam melting.
Fig. 1
Morphologies of the silicon ingot and the cross section

Section2.Heading: Oxygen content during the EBM process
Section2.Para:
The concentration of oxygen as a function of time, along with the power of 15 kW, is shown in Fig. 2.
Fig. 2
Oxygen content as a function of time at constant powers

The sample used for electron beam melting was taken from the bottom of the casting ingot. Since the sample was in contact with the SiO2 crucible, the oxygen concentration was high with the value of 6.177 ppmw. Although the temperature was 1,687 K when silicon was melted completely, the removal of oxygen was very effective in that period. The oxygen concentration was reduced to 1.629 ppmw when the sample was completely melted by EBM, i.e., the oxygen was reduced 73.6 % at 0 s. After 600 s of melting, the oxygen concentration was reduced to lower than 0.0571 ppmw.

The oxygen in the sample was significantly reduced up to 73.6 % when it was first melted. The sample that was melted for 600 s showed a lower 0.0571 ppmw concentration equivalent to 99.08 % of oxygen, leaving behind almost oxygen-free silicon. So far, the EBM method can be considered the most effective and efficient process for oxygen removal from silicon.

Section2.Heading: Thermodynamic analysis of oxygen removal from silicon
Section2.Para:
During the melting process, the oxygen atoms are transported onto the melt surface and react with the surface silicon atoms to produce SiO gas. After that, the resultant SiO gas evaporates from the melt surface, which is regarded as a main mechanism for oxygen removal [16]. The saturated vapor pressure of pure substance is only a function of temperature. As for SiO, it increases from 2.79 × 102 to 4.18 × 106 Pa when the temperature changes from 1,600 to 2,600 K, [17] as shown in Fig. 3, which is much larger than the vapor pressure under experimental conditions. During melting process, silicon is melted for quite a long time at a high temperature, so oxygen can be removed efficiently. Meanwhile, silicon substrate also evaporates with the removal of oxygen. However, the difference between the saturated vapor pressure of SiO and silicon is very large above the melting point of silicon, so the evaporation capacity of silicon is much less than that of SiO.
Fig. 3
Vapor pressure of SiO and silicon as a function of temperature

The rate of ideal evaporation, J (mol/m2 s), into a vacuum varies with temperature according to the Hertz–Knudsen–Langmuir equation: 1
$$ J_{i} = \frac{{P_{i} }}{{\sqrt {2\pi RTM_{i} } }} $$

During the vacuum melting process, the impurity element was either evaporated or enriched at the surface depending on the evaporation rate of the impurity element and the matrix material. A melt contained a g of matrix silicon and b g of SiO; once the vacuum was applied, the x g of the silicon and the y g of SiO were evaporated. Equation (3) as [18]: 3

If α is <1, oxygen is concentrated in molten silicon; if α is larger than 1, oxygen can be removed from molten silicon; and if α is equal to 1, the concentration of oxygen is unchanged in molten silicon.

The temperature and evaporation coefficient of molten silicon are inversely related. However, the evaporation coefficient of SiO in molten silicon was much >1, indicating that it was evaporated away from the melting silicon. Therefore, in the initial phase, most of the oxygen impurities were separated from molten silicon into the gas phase and then pumped out by the vacuum system, thus resulting in significantly lower oxygen impurity content.

Section2.Heading: Analysis of the silicon loss during oxygen removal process
Section2.Para:
The evaporation rate of silicon was employed to calculate the average surface temperature of the melt. Fig. 5 shows the evaporation weight loss of silicon as a function of time. The evaporation weight loss of silicon increased as the melting time of EBM increased.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: The oxygen content in silicon decreased rapidly within the time range of approximately 0–600 s and tended to level out afterward. Furthermore, the concentration of oxygen in silicon significantly decreased at constant EBM power with increased time. In addition, oxygen content decreased to 0.0571 ppmw at 15 kW after 600 s in the EBM treatment, which is a 99.08 % reduction of the oxygen. During the melting process, the loss of silicon is very small, with an evaporation rate of 1.10 × 10−5 kg/s. The loss of silicon could be controlled up to 1.7 % during the oxygen removal process to a desirable value, indicating EBM as an effective method to remove oxygen from silicon and decrease the loss of silicon.
